text:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Electronics
Daily \-- Investigators publish new report on Nanotechnology - Nanomaterials.
According to news reporting from Chico, California, by NewsRx journalists,
research stated, "In recent years, functional electronic nanomaterials have
made significant strides from advancements in the interplay of physics,
chemistry, materials science, and computational research."

Financial support for this research came from U.S. Department of Energy,
Office of Science, Office of Workforce Development for Teachers and Scientists
(WDTS) under the Visiting Faculty Program (VFP).

The news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from California
State University, "However, synthetically tunable electronic materials are a
long-standing, but elusive, technological goal. More recently, metal-organic
frameworks (MOFs), a class of nanoporous, hybrid inorganic-organic crystalline
solids, have garnered attention as a novel class of electronic nanomaterials."

According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "The aim of this
perspective is to (i) highlight the charge transport behavior of recently
discovered (2017-2019) electronic MOFs and (ii) recommend future directions
for improvement of intrinsically and extrinsically conductive MOFs for MOF-
based electronics."

For more information on this research see: Charge Transport In Metal-organic
Frameworks for Electronics Applications. _APL Materials_ , 2020;8(5):. _APL
Materials_ can be contacted at: Amer Inst Physics, 1305 Walt Whitman Rd, Ste
300, Melville, NY 11747-4501, USA.

Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by
contacting M.C. So, California State University, Dept. of Chemistry and
Biochemistry, Chico, CA 95973, United States. Additional authors for this
research include J.J. Calvo and S.M. Angel.

The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is:
<https://doi.org/10.1063/1.5143590>. This DOI is a link to an online
electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your
direct source for a journal article and its citation.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around
the world.)

title: Researchers from California State University Provide Details of New Studies and Findings in the Area of Nanomaterials (Charge Transport In Metal-organic Frameworks for Electronics Applications): Nanotechnology - Nanomaterials
html:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Electronics Daily -- Investigators publish new report on Nanotechnology - Nanomaterials. According to news reporting from Chico, California, by NewsRx journalists, research stated, “In recent years, functional electronic nanomaterials have made significant strides from advancements in the interplay of physics, chemistry, materials science, and computational research.”

Financial support for this research came from U.S. Department of Energy, Office of Science, Office of Workforce Development for Teachers and Scientists (WDTS) under the Visiting Faculty Program (VFP).

The news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from California State University, “However, synthetically tunable electronic materials are a long-standing, but elusive, technological goal. More recently, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), a class of nanoporous, hybrid inorganic-organic crystalline solids, have garnered attention as a novel class of electronic nanomaterials.”

According to the news reporters, the research concluded: “The aim of this perspective is to (i) highlight the charge transport behavior of recently discovered (2017-2019) electronic MOFs and (ii) recommend future directions for improvement of intrinsically and extrinsically conductive MOFs for MOF-based electronics.”

For more information on this research see: Charge Transport In Metal-organic Frameworks for Electronics Applications. APL Materials, 2020;8(5):. APL Materials can be contacted at: Amer Inst Physics, 1305 Walt Whitman Rd, Ste 300, Melville, NY 11747-4501, USA.

Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by contacting M.C. So, California State University, Dept. of Chemistry and Biochemistry, Chico, CA 95973, United States. Additional authors for this research include J.J. Calvo and S.M. Angel.

The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.1063/1.5143590. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around the world.)
